title: Edmond L. DePatie
text:
Edmond L. DePatie (27 January 1900 – 6 August 1966) was an <a href="Cinema%20of%20the%20United%20States">American film industry</a> executive. He was vice president and general manager of <a href="Warner%20Bros.">Warner Bros.</a> Burbank studio, and on 18 April, 1966 at the <a href="38th%20Academy%20Awards">38th Academy Awards</a>, DePatie was honored with the <a href="Jean%20Hersholt%20Humanitarian%20Award">Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award</a>, just four months before his death.
He succeeded Jean Hersholt as president of the <a href="Motion%20Picture%20%26amp%3B%20Television%20Fund">Motion Picture Relief Fund</a> in 1955, later launching a campaign for the establishment of a Motion Picture Exposition and Hall of Fame to honor filmmaking and to bring in revenue for the Motion Picture & Television Fund Country House. These plans were not successful, and despite the efforts of many over the years, a Hollywood Museum that benefits the Country House has not become a reality.
He died of a heart attack while vacationing in <a href="Chowchilla%2C%20California">Chowchilla</a>, <a href="California">California</a> on 6 August 1966, aged 66.
